Award.AwardTitle: CRII: III: RUI: Effective Protein Characterization via Fast Exact Open Modification Searching

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proteins form the major building blocks of cells, and protein-protein interactions provide information about cell functions. Characterizing these interactions is made possible through mass spectrometry (MS), a technique that breaks down complex biological samples into much simpler ions and measures their individual masses. Computer algorithms can then be used to interpret the output of MS experiments. The advent of tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS), also known as shotgun proteomics, led to a huge increase in the speed with which researchers can execute proteomics experiments, which in turn has enabled the creation of massive databases containing millions of known spectra. This research will create novel algorithms that will be able to quickly identify which proteins exist in a biological sample by comparing unknown spectra from the sample against entire libraries of known spectra. Ultimately, this project will make it easier for humans to understand the molecular basis of disease and will enable personalized medicine and identifying new drugs to tackle currently incurable diseases.

The goal of this project is to develop novel methods for protein characterization in MS/MS experiment results that will provide increased spectral match effectiveness while scaling to search the largest existing protein databases and beyond. The key computational component in shotgun proteomics is matching MS/MS spectra against theoretical spectra or actual spectra in spectral databases to identify possible peptides (protein sections). In essence, given a translation of the spectra to points in the Euclidean space and a chosen proximity function, the algorithmic component in the search is a nearest neighbor search algorithm. Due to the large size of spectral databases, the problem has been traditionally solved through a variety of approximate nearest neighbor search methods and a combination of vector space and probabilistic proximity measures which are often not scalable and lead to missed spectral matches. This project aims to address these limitations in two ways. First, it will develop novel filtering-based exact nearest neighbor search methods for the shifted dot-product proximity measure, which has been recently shown to outperform alternatives by accounting for spectral post translational modifications while searching for matches. The proposed filtering-based methods prune much of the search space by eliminating potential candidates without computing their proximity to the query, based on their composition and on theoretic properties of the proximity measure. Second, the project will develop effective decomposition techniques for the inherently irregular computation requirements of the proposed pruning-based search that will enable distributed methods to search the largest proteomics databases of today, and beyond. The project will result in the dissemination of the developed methods to the large computational genomics community and will involve research education of underrepresented undergraduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Santa Clara University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF SANTA CLARA COLLEGE

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we worked to develop methods for effective and efficient search of massive spectral libraries, which are databases of mass spectrometry (MS/MS)-based chemical compound analysis results that have been previously annotated with an associated peptide. These compounds were represented as sparse vectors and we developed a sparse nearest neighbor search library that could be used to identify exact matches in the database efficiently. While searches with our library were very efficient, they did not ultimately improve search effectiveness significantly compared to baselines which were continuously improving over the span of the project. However, our team was able to use methods we designed as part of this project to solve problems in two separate domains, clustering high-dimensional single-cell datasets and detecting the severity of kidney failure in chronic kidney disease patients. In the first domain, we developed a method for Cosine-based Tanimoto similarity-refined graph for community detection using Leiden’s algorithm (CosTaL), which can be used to analyze large-sized multidimensional single-cell datasets through community detection in a Cosine-based Tanimoto similarity-refined graph constructed over mass-cytometry data. The proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art baselines and is at the same time very efficient. In the second domain, we proposed the selective partitioned regression algorithm for accurate health monitoring, a cost-effective machine learning-based testing system designed to enable affordable yet precise kidney health assessments. While still in early stages of development, our initial study indicates that SPR can be an effective tool for detecting the severity of kidney disease using inexpensive lateral flow assay test strips and a smart phone-based application.


Through this research project, the PI recruited and advised his first Ph.D students. The research results have been published in 2 journal manuscripts and presented at 1 conference. The project involved and trained 4 graduate students, 7 undergraduate students and 3 high-school students, including 2 female university students and 3 female high-school students. The high school students have since pursued degrees in STEM fields at nationally ranked universities and all but two of the undergraduate and graduate students currently hold software engineering or data scientist positions at prominent companies such as Microsoft, Alphabet, and Amazon. The PI has integrated the research findings in projects in an undergraduate course and several seminar and invited talks. 3 software tools have been developed and made publicly available as a result of this research project. 


Last Modified: 04/12/2024
Modified by: David C Anastasiu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In this project, we worked to develop methods for effective and efficient search of massive spectral libraries, which are databases of mass spectrometry (MS/MS)-based chemical compound analysis results that have been previously annotated with an associated peptide. These compounds were represented as sparse vectors and we developed a sparse nearest neighbor search library that could be used to identify exact matches in the database efficiently. While searches with our library were very efficient, they did not ultimately improve search effectiveness significantly compared to baselines which were continuously improving over the span of the project. However, our team was able to use methods we designed as part of this project to solve problems in two separate domains, clustering high-dimensional single-cell datasets and detecting the severity of kidney failure in chronic kidney disease patients. In the first domain, we developed a method for Cosine-based Tanimoto similarity-refined graph for community detection using Leidens algorithm (CosTaL), which can be used to analyze large-sized multidimensional single-cell datasets through community detection in a Cosine-based Tanimoto similarity-refined graph constructed over mass-cytometry data. The proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art baselines and is at the same time very efficient. In the second domain, we proposed the selective partitioned regression algorithm for accurate health monitoring, a cost-effective machine learning-based testing system designed to enable affordable yet precise kidney health assessments. While still in early stages of development, our initial study indicates that SPR can be an effective tool for detecting the severity of kidney disease using inexpensive lateral flow assay test strips and a smart phone-based application. Through this research project, the PI recruited and advised his first Ph.D students. The research results have been published in 2 journal manuscripts and presented at 1 conference. The project involved and trained 4 graduate students, 7 undergraduate students and 3 high-school students, including 2 female university students and 3 female high-school students. The high school students have since pursued degrees in STEM fields at nationally ranked universities and all but two of the undergraduate and graduate students currently hold software engineering or data scientist positions at prominent companies such as Microsoft, Alphabet, and Amazon. The PI has integrated the research findings in projects in an undergraduate course and several seminar and invited talks. 3 software tools have been developed and made publicly available as a result of this research project.
